citation.article-title: Sphingomonas hankookensis sp. nov., isolated from wastewater
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Description of Sphingomonas hankookensis sp. nov.
Sphingomonas hankookensis (han.kook.en′sis. N.L. fem. adj. hankookensis of Hankook, the Korean name for South Korea from where the type strain was isolated).
Cells are Gram-negative, non-motile rods (0.3–0.6×0.9–2.8 μm).
Colonies on TSA are circular, convex, smooth, yellow and 0.8–1.0 mm in diameter after incubation for 3 days at 30 °C.
Growth occurs at 4 and 37 °C, but not at 40 °C.
Optimal pH for growth is around 7.0.
Growth occurs at pH 5.0 and 10.0, but not at pH 4.5 or 10.5.
Growth occurs in the presence of 0–1 % (w/v) NaCl (optimum 0–0.5 %, w/v).
Negative for arginine dihydrolase, lysine decarboxylase, ornithine decarboxylase and tryptophan deaminase.
H2S and indole are not produced.
Tweens 20, 40 and 60 are hydrolysed, but xanthine, hypoxanthine and tyrosine are not.
Susceptible to chloramphenicol, gentamicin, neomycin, novobiocin, oleandomycin and tetracycline and weakly susceptible to kanamycin and polymyxin B.
Resistant to ampicillin, carbenicillin, cephalothin, lincomycin, penicillin G and streptomycin.
The major fatty acids (>10 % of the total) are C18 : 1ω7c, C16 : 1ω7c and/or iso-C15 : 0 2-OH, and C16 : 0.
Other phenotypic characteristics are given in Table 2.
The type strain, ODN7T (=KCTC 22579T=CCUG 57509T), was isolated from a wastewater treatment plant in Taejon, Korea.
The DNA G+C content of the type strain is 67.2 mol% (determined by HPLC).
